title: Inigo Martinez : From Barcelona fifth - choice centre - back to El Clasico contender

This is how Inigo Martinez jokingly described his past week at Barcelona, which has without question been his best time since joining them on a free transfer in the summer.
Head coach Xavi subbed him off in the 82nd minute of Wednesdayâ€™s 2-1 Champions League home win over Shakhtar Donetsk, but not because his performance had been disappointing â€” far from it.

Xavi also confirmed there was â€œnothing to worry aboutâ€ in his post-match comments. Quite the opposite. Just as he did against former club Athletic Bilbao in La Liga on Sunday night, Martinez managed to prove a point to anyone who was still wondering why Barca moved for him.
The Catalans did not have their brightest match against Shakhtar, but they got the three points that leave them comfortably top of their group at the halfway stage, thanks most of all to a brilliant display from 20-year-old Fermin Lopez, who scored one goal and provided the other for Ferran Torres.
La Masia graduates such as Lopez have taken all the headlines this past week in Barcelona, but apart from 17-year-old Marc Guiuâ€™s fairytale winner at the weekend, there has been arguably no better revelation than Martinez.
This is partly because of how underappreciated he has been since arriving.
Just before the formal announcement of his transfer, as a free agent after his Bilbao contract expired, Martinez had to have surgery on a foot injury. That left him facing a rough start to the campaign, with no game time in the warm-up matches as we went through a careful recovery process.
It was even easy to forget Martinez was part of the squad, and itâ€™s fair to say Barcelona had some responsibility for that.
As the Catalans were immersed in their usual salary limit difficulties, his injury served as a reason to put his registration with La Liga on hold. His recuperation meant he could not play at the time, while other new signings, such as Ilkay Gundogan and Oriol Romeu could. Therefore, the backroom staff preferred to prioritise them.
As deadline day arrived, though, Martinez found himself in a difficult position.

Still on the comeback trail, he was the fifth-choice centre-back of the squad, with Ronald Araujo, Jules Kounde, Andreas Christensen and Eric Garcia all ahead of him. He was still not even registered.
One of the reasons Barcelona finally allowed Garcia to go on loan to Girona, as well as sending Ansu Fati to Brighton for the season and selling Abde Ezzalzouli to Real Betis was to make sure theyâ€™d have enough salary space to register Martinez.

The player and his camp were always calm about this situation and trusted the club would register him eventually. Senior Barca executives acknowledged it would be seen as a disaster if they could not. This was a big motivation in allowing those deadline-day departures.
With all the paperwork sorted and after two substitute appearances, Martinez finally made his first start on September 26 in a 2-2 La Liga draw away to Mallorca, he was lacking rhythm and didnâ€™t offer his best performance.
When Kounde was then ruled out with an injury suffered in the final game before the October internationals, Martinez was presented with a new opportunity in this crowded week of football. â€œHeâ€™s certainly taken his chance,â€ said a dressing room source, who preferred to speak anonymously as they did not have permission to comment.
If there is a department in which Martinez has shone brightest, it is his work with the ball. He played a fundamental role in the build-up process both on Wednesday and at the weekend.
Letâ€™s start with the Shakhtar one.
In the screengrab below, Martinez receives the ball from Araujo, and while the opposition sit back and wait for Barcelona to attack, he makes a pass to Torres that instantly breaks two linesâ€¦
â€¦creating space for him to turn and start the run that ends in Lopezâ€™s goal to double the lead.
Even more impressive was what Martinez did three days earlier against his former club.
It is practically the same context, but arguably a harder pass to a) spot and b) execute. In this case, Joao Felix is the target for Martinez.
The distance the ball has to cover is slightly further, but Martinez finds a way through. Joao Felix shows sublime control before launching the hero of the night, 17-year-old Guiu, on towards his winner.
That kind of passing has not been seen from a Barcelona centre-back this season. Their most remarkable actions have mostly been desperate tackles, such as the one Kounde made Porto in the previous Champions League group game three weeks ago to deny Evanilson a goal.

Martinez has impressed with his defensive actions too, but also with his passes through opposition lines and his long balls to switch play â€” an ability Xavi values.
â€œHeâ€™s really proactive in defence,â€ the manager said on Wednesday night. â€œHe knows how to filter balls straight to the forwards. His passes are so good, as we could see with Ferminâ€™s goal, but heâ€™s also really good at switching the game with long-range deliveries. Iâ€™m so pleased with him â€” thatâ€™s why we signed him.â€
Against Shakhtar, Martinez completed five long passes from seven attempts â€” the most among Barcelona players in the game. But he was even more impressive in this department against previous club Bilbao on Saturday, where he completed 12 from 15 attempts in the same metric â€” again, the best numbers in the team. In both matches, his passing accuracy was above 90 per cent.
Xavi also praised Martinezâ€™s influence in the dressing room. Among the young core of players now growing at the club, a figure with his great experience is proving to be a fitting addition.
â€œInigo is extremely positive for the group. He has the character of a leader,â€ Xavi said. â€œHe is very positive and knows what he can offer to the younger ones.â€
Martinez was one of the first players to offer advice to Guiu after his winner on Saturday, as the 17-year-old revealed on TV: â€œInigo just told me I wonâ€™t be able to sleep, but to enjoy it.â€
Dressing room sources say heâ€™s also close to Gavi, Pedri and Alejandro Balde, players he already knew from the Spanish national team, as well as Lopez and 16-year-old Lamine Yamal, plus fellow experienced campaigners such as Romeu, Marcos Alonso and Sergi Roberto.
Now the first Clasico of the season is looming, and in these two games, Martinez has offered Xavi reasons to consider him as a potential starter in Saturdayâ€™s La Liga meeting at Montjuic, Barcaâ€™s temporary home while the Camp Nou undergoes extensive and expensive renovations. Picking him would allow the manager to repeat his successful formula of using Araujo as a right-back against Vinicius Junior.

This is certainly a nice problem to have for Xavi now. And it is a significant achievement for somebody who not so long ago was an unnoticed signing, fifth-choice at centre-back and a last-minute registration.
